frameDefinitions: An Agent, Situation or Entity has an influence on a Cognizer.
This frame contains words that necessarily indicate the motion of two distinct objects.
An Agent intentionally seeks to bring about an internal mental or emotional state in the Experiencer.
An event resumes at a certain Place and Time.  NB:  Refer to Event frame.  '' 'Both matches will resume tomorrow, after a day of rest.'
A Cognizer_agent attempts to find some Sought_entity by examining some Ground.
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
frameExamples: These works had a profound effect and <t>influenced</t> her in the creation of a successful series capturing this sun-drenched region.
She <t>accompanied</t> him in the ambulance to Hollywood Memorial Hospital.
Both matches will <t>resume</t> tomorrow, after a day of rest.
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
listRoleDefinitions: The person who is influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A state of affairs--- which can be an event, state or conditions---that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
A person or thing that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
An Action that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> decides to carry out as a consequence of the influence of a <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A <fen>Behavior</fen> that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is engaged in independently but whose execution is subsequently influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
An entity that stands metonymically for the actions and considerations that produced it.
The <fen>Agent</fen> acts to influence a <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the Subjective_influencing event occurs.
The location in which one has influence.
This is the entity, frequently a living being, which moves in relation to the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. Normally the <fen>Theme</fen> frame element is expressed as an external argument.
This frame element is the second moving object, expressed as a direct object or an oblique:

<fen>Source</fen> marks any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the motion of the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the  object expresses the starting point of motion. With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

<fen>Path</fen> marks phrases that describe the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen>'s trajectory of motion and which are neither expressions of the  <fen>Source</fen> nor the <fen>Goal</fen> of motion. The notion <fen>Path</fen> also includes directional expressions.

Any expression which tells where the <fen>Cotheme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Note that if the <fen>Cotheme</fen> is animate, the <fen>Theme</fen> need not also end up in the same place. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

<fen>Area</fen> marks expressions which describe a general area in which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
Phrases that denote a physical path on which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place are marked <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> move.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location which provides a setting for a defined motion (that is one with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Agent</fen> is an External Argument of the target word and purposefully arouses an emotional state.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person the <fen>Agent</fen> causes to have a particular emotional state.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> affects the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> affects the <fen>Experiencer</fen>
The <fen>Process</fen> which is being resumed.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The person who attempts to find the Sought_entity.
This is the entity that the <fen>Ground</fen> may contain. Typically, it is expressed as a <ment>for</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Seeking occurs.
A spatial setting larger than the <fen>Ground</fen> in which the Seeking event occurs.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
listRoleExamples: George Gilder would run with this idea later in writing the New Testament of supply-side economics that influenced <fex>Reagan</fex>.
<fex>The balmy temperatures</fex> inspired me to write a poem on the advent of spring.
<fex>The painting</fex> inspired me to take a risk and use the intense green for the sky.
What factors influenced Nixon <fex>to issue the doctrine</fex>?
Attention will also be paid to St. Paul , what influenced him <fex>in his thinking</fex> and what he wrote in his letters about sex, sexuality, men and women
Does anyone know what inspired <fex>this song</fex>?
Chavez has much influence <fex>in South America</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> accompanied me for five miles in a blue Toyota.
Pat accompanied <fex>me</fex> down the street.
The cat chased the mouse <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The bikers followed the truck <fex>west</fex>.
The children chased the ball <fex>into the park</fex>. (The children end up in the park.)
The police followed the suspects <fex>all around town</fex>.
The police followed the suspect <fex>on the interstate</fex> for several miles.
The tracking dogs chased their target <fex>towards the river</fex>, where they lost it.
<fex>The meeting</fex> resumed after the bomb threat passed.
<fex>John</fex> looked for his pencil.
Leslie examined the glass <fex>for cracks</fex>.
The police were hunting for evidence in my house <fex>yesterday</fex>
<fex>In Paris</fex> police were hunting for suspects in two of the city's southerns suburbs today
<fex>Chapter 6</fex> admonishes readers to quit smoking.
